one_liners: Hi! My name is Santiago and I was born and raised in Mexico
paragraphs: my mother got my sister and I the privilege of going to fancy schools and learning english. I then got the chance of going on to learn french at another - even fancier - place, and getting several scholarships to study what I love most in the lovely maple land of Canada.
I'm on a journey to be reliable and competent, to be able to give back to the people that have pushed me forward and -very ambitiously- be worthy of dealing with our biggest challenges.
at the University of Montreal, I came to the USA to work, and to learn how massive, complex, distributed systems work. I wanted to see my textbooks come to life.
as an Infrastructure engineer. I'm profoundly grateful to be where I am, and I'm thankful for my excelent peers, and for what I sincerely think is leadership with a clear vision and good direction.

playing the guitar; reading - especially about social action and topics adjacent to the field I love most (don't tell anyone, but it's computer related); I have some weird obsession with water, its sports, particularily those I'm terrible at. Like rowing with the UdeM's team, it's pretty fun to scream synchronously with a bunch of charismatic strangers while desperately trying not to tip over.

and communicating science; I've met all kinds of people throughout my life and our different tastes, talents, experience, backgrounds, handicaps and challenges have taught me more than I could ever repay. That might be why I ended up teaching over 1500 students during my undergrad - which, honestly, still feels surreal. I feel like by teaching, I pay back just a bit of that debt and I also learn so, so, so much.

I've been getting a little obsessed with AI, computing and computational biology. If you had told my child self what we can do with computers now, he would've never believed you. I hope I can make it even harder to believe.

descriptions: Figma since 2023: Mainly learning A LOT. Working on maintaining our file and ML infrastructure through huge growth in scale, both in features and in traffic. The work is by nature very result focused, so the tools I use vary significantly. However I've done a lot of --Ruby, --TypeScript, --Terraform --and AWS work. --I've had to learn to understand code regardless of language however. --Migrating from and deprecating a major service (All of our thumbnailing and our REST API's backend). --AI Search Infrastructure

From the moment I landed in Montreal, fall 2021, to the moment I left for NYC - end of summer 2023- I worked as a Teacher Assistant for 11 classes -across 6 courses- and amounting to ~1650 students (not accounting for overlap): --Programming 101 with Python with professor Marc Feeley and lecturer Olivier Melançon (for 3 terms) --Programming Language Concepts and Paradigms with professor Stefan Monnier (for 2 terms): worked mainly with Haskell, Elisp, Prolog, C, Rust and Java --Discrete Structures in Computer Science with professor Miklós Csűrös (for 2 terms): teaching the discrete structures -and fundamentals- from mathematics that we most commonly use as computer scientists --Web development and design with Sébastien Roy (for 2 terms) --Software Engineering with Dr Amal Ben Abdellah --Advanced Java Concepts with lecturer Michel Reid

During the summer of 2022: I Implemented experimental features, documented and debugged on Ixiasoft's DITA CCMS web application for technical documentation. Mainly worked with: --Java, --TypeScript, --React (by itself and with Redux), --and Apache. --Also handled -to a lesser extent- Maven and CSS.
Current average of 3.75/4.3 (A-)
Consulting director at 180DC UdeM
Mention très bien: TB (18.25/20)
Founder and captain of the machine learning club
Member of the programming club
I'm learning to make videogames with my friends; we're a small team and I'm the only technical person. Using Godot.

This is a research and development project under Mila - Quebec AI Institute's supervision. The climate is chaotic, but modeling it has advantages, from weather forecasting to event planning, agriculture, and the economy. Thusly, climate models at different scales would be a powerful tool for our societies. Currently, we have access to global climate models, but they are based on large-scale measurements. At smaller scales, data can be unreliable, leading to incorrect conclusions. I have the opportunity to lead a team that aims to build on the state of the art to solve this problem like no one has before. I made a website for it which you can access here:

This is a research and development project under Mila - Quebec AI Institute's supervision. Sentiment analysis is a very important aspect in companies, especially in terms of customer experience. Indeed, sentiment analysis is a natural language processing application that aims to identify the different tones found in texts. Especially with the huge wave of popularity with social media, sentiment analysis is becoming even more important. In this project, we explore machine learning and deep learning techniques in natural language processing (NLP) to identify sentiments in texts. I made a website for it which you can access here:

This is a research and development project for UdeM's Laboratory of Computational and Theoretical Biology. Researched and implemented an API for genome assembly refinement, as well as a binning scheme data structure, using JAVA and the htsjdk library. The work is thoroughly documented and explained here:

This is a research and development project for UdeM's Laboratory of 3D Computer Vision. Implemented and compared several CNN architectures based on GC-Net by Kendal et al. Worked using Mathematica. The model is able to do binocular stereoscopy: it can determine depth based on two images, a bit like human eyes! I mainly experimented with variations in depth and with use of residual nets, and was interested by estimation quality as well as computational expense. You can access the code, analysis and trained models here:

Worked on various machine learning models for supervised learning tasks, such as regression and classification. Implemented with Python. From scratch: non-parametric models such as KNN and Parzen Windows (with Gaussian kernel); and parametric models such as a perceptron (logistic regressor) and a SVM (with and without kernel). With libraries: neural networks, CNNs, and SVMs. And tested them with several databases, like bank records, phone records or image datasets (like MNIST).
We implemented a 'File Allocation Table'-based storage management system using C for a 32-bit Linux system. In human talk: we built the file -and memory- management section of an operating system.

Planned then built a small database for a library. In the planning, we used formal methods for entity-relationship modelling, then relational modelling, relational algebra, request optimization and database normalization. For the implementation, we used SQL, Hibernate (Java) and Maven for compilation and delivery of the executable.

Partitioned and preprocessed a database, built and trained a convolutional neural network model, exported and then implemented it into a dynamic web platform. I built the latter using Flask (Python) and Jinja.

A functioning app developed with Java that includes an interactive graphical interface and a data management system. We went through the rigorous planning expected from engineers: planning, interviews, prioritization, use case definitions, analysis (risks, non-functional requirements, materials, constraints), modeling (VPP), design, prototyping, automatic testing (JUnit), team management and scheduling, and last (but not least) documentation (Javadoc).

School project for object-oriented programming with Java; it's a small window. Using JavaFX, we (2 people) made a fancy window with 2 counters: you can add and subtract, divide and multiply, undo and redo. Every action performed in the app was temporarily saved, and as such the actions log was always available for exporting as a .txt file.

A Pseudo-Lisp interpreter made with Haskell: Built the interpretation and evaluation section of a Haskell program that could read and execute files from a Lisp-inspired language. Dealt with functions, closure, environments, variables, recursion and recursive definitions, etc... the whole enchilada. Then built a Pseudo-Haskell interpreter, where I used Prolog for interpreting and executing, same features as before, but with added type inference.

Using object-oriented programming we made an environmental simulation program. It read XML files describing animals or plants and simulated them for a certain amount of epochs: the way they interacted, what they ate, their energy consumption, whether they died or reproduced, and so on.
Originally made from scratch with HTML, CSS, JavaScript, jQuery as well as the Animate on Scroll library. Currently built with React, TypeScript, JSON, CSS... and a sprinkle of love!
I like teaching!

From mathematical modelling and computational biology to drug discovery and immunology, I think there's a lot of opportunity to facilitate medical advancements taking advantage of our computing resources. And that potential is easily the most exciting prospect to me.

It's also only natural for me to be interested after Google DeepMind's breakthrough of protein structure prediction, and subsequent publication of their prediction database. As if it were telling us: 'yes, it can be easier and faster. Yes, some of your illnesses could be cured following this example.'

I care about other people, I'd like them to live dignified lives and to be able to enjoy themselves. It also seems obviously preferable to live surrounded with happy, healthy people -who can help, too- than otherwise.
I'm not sure if it's the most efficient approach. But who cares when you get to see the smile of someone who've you've helped, even if just for a bit?

Now, I love algorithms as much as any other guy, but some problems are very hard to solve by traditional algorithms. And they happen to be almost trivial with these sophisticated (and too often obfuscated) statistical and probabilistic methods.
... and yeah I also like the self driving cars, the smart personal assistants and the AI artists.

In fact, all the images from the experience section, and those of Medicine, Social Action and AI in the interests section were generated by DALL-E! An Open AI image generation model; which, like the rest of their work, is excellent.
It was the future, its now the present.
Our capacity to properly network computational power, and to transfer information efficiently and accessibly is - to me - one of the greatest steps forward for democracy in history.
I'm also a huge nerd, so I like the maths and the technology behind it.
A natural progression from my interest in graphics, as well as my long-lived love for games - video or otherwise.
I feel like game development would let me be my most creative self, and that's someone I'd like to meet.

There's just something so fascinating about all the little math and psychology tricks behind making a 2D screen and a fancy calculator fool a person into thinking they're looking at a 3D object. I also like being fooled with pretty, non existant, 3D objects myself.
On top of that GPUs are by far the fastest developping computer component nowadays. I'd really like to better understand how they work, to exploit their full potential.
Ok honestly if you don't think robots are at least a little cool we can't be friends.
On a more serious note, robotics seems like the future of physical processes and manipulations, everywhere from medicine to manufacturing and transport.
How could I not be interested?!
Specially how to deal with very limited physical space and adverse physical conditions for hardware.
I'm interested in knowing how we could program computers that don't get the same luxuries in stability and space as our normal computers.
How do we ensure maintainable, fast and reliable systems in these environments?

articles.title: On Learning and Teaching
articles.description: Reflections on how to study, learn and teach effectively.
contents: In this article I’ll be sharing what I’ve learned, both as a student and as a teacher over the years. The main focus will be finding effective approaches to learning and from these enunciate effective approaches to teaching.

When I mention good teachers throughout the article, there’s an implicit recognition that bad teachers exist. Bad teachers -I believe- are good teachers to be; because teaching is a skill which is learnable.
**Effective practice:**
Practice makes perfect. Well not quite, but practice does make it BETTER. I feel like the The Parable of the Pottery Class illustrates this in the most succinct form:

There was once a pottery teacher called Brian. One month, he decided to split his class into two groups. Group A had to make a pot every day for 30 days (so 30 pots in total). Group B had to work on a single pot for the whole 30 days.                    At the end of the month, Brian judged the quality of the pots. Without exception, every one of the top 10 pots came from Group A, the guys that made one pot per day. None came from the group that focused on perfecting their single pot.

Fine. But not everything is easily practiced! Aha! Now here’s where we must be creative. If to learn effectively we must practice time and time again, then we must find a way to turn any learnable topic into a practice-able topic. The steps are as follows:                    Build a safe space to fail.                    Get Strong Feedback: strong feedback is fast, frequent and actionable.

Games do this excellently, and you’ll find that players who play more typically are significantly better than those who play less. This is because games are made in a way that optimizes for effective practice:                     If you fail, you can play again and you’re fine (it is safe).                     When you fail you immediately know, and you can try again (Strong Feedback)

Good teachers will create a safe space to fail in their classes, and provide strong feedback.                    Good teachers will also fail students who failed to assimilate the material, with the intent of giving them more time to do so. A safe space is not a justification to normalize mediocrity, and indeed its existence is likely to have the students excel regardless.
**The abstract and the concrete.**
Nice! Now we can learn things. But how do we remember them?

Neural Networks work through weighted associations. The brain, although significantly more complex, works similarly: the stronger the association, the more powerful the connection.                    A memory which is strongly bound to an event will be recalled when the event takes place (think of the breeze caressing the grass coming to mind with the sound of the wind, or pure -distilled- ire upon seeing a League of Legends lobby with that one guy you played with a year ago).
Cool. Let 's exploit that.

Not everything you want to remember is strongly associated to an event, nor necessarily to another memory. So how do we amend that? Easy! Make associations.                     This is the principle behind mnemonics or why Kurzgesagt videos feel so much easier to remember: by associating new information with strongly settled memories (by which I mean, things you remember easily, and have seen a thousand times) you get all the memorizing your brain has already worked on for the existing memory, almost for free!

You just need to create a strong enough association now! To do so, there are 2 steps:                    Make it interesting (there’s a reason why we call it memorable!)                    Make it reasonable (make it easy to reconstruct if you forget the association).

Good teachers exploit this by using props (associate the abstract to concrete, real objects, which are well familiar to our mammalian brains) and by using carefully crafted and curated examples, which relate the material to the daily lives of students (think of the 20-7 watermelons that Michael had to buy, or the (RED ^ -BLUE) cable to cut in the ticking time bomb).
**Pay. Attention.**

Humans are amazing at multitasking, but we’re terrible at multi-thinking. My idea of why this happens is based on Daniel Kahneman’s work, and I’d explain my reasoning as follows:                    System 2 thinking is brilliant in parallelizing, because there are no profound considerations to be made, your intuition can make easy decisions quickly and in parallel.                     System 1 thinking is expensive and deliberate. If you get distracted, you’re effectively disconnecting parts of your System 1 computer, and handicapping any chance you have of thinking, learning and remembering effectively.
Please focus.                    A good teacher will find ways to get students to focus during class.
**Things making sense**

It’s fundamental that the material being thought is coherent end to end. The material should be self contained, or at least enlist all its dependencies so students can quickly identify and fill in the gaps. Kind of like good software!

Incoherent material won’t be trusted, and will be forgotten with a lot more ease.                    Incoherent material, even if useful, won't be used as often, because the students won’t know how to explain it.
**The Importance of Peers and discussions.**

Finally, nothing great is learned alone. Many replace live discussions by the reading and writing of papers, books, letters, or forum discussions, but every significant step towards learning (and symmetrically, towards teaching) is given through communicating with others.

Talking* with a mentor or a peer about a problem, or a topic, or indeed anything where insight is to be made, is one of the most effective and productive ways to learn. A healthy conversation forces us to employ all the mechanisms discussed in this article:                     Effective practice: a healthy discussion has a back and forward, where one can be wrong many times, corrected, and quickly re-engage in conversation.                    The abstract and the concrete: your peers will stop listening to you if you’re too abstract.                    Pay. Attention: on the flipside people will be disgruntled (scary!) if you don’t pay attention to them when they’re directly talking with you (I would know, I space out all the time, sorry).                    Things making sense: incoherence will be interrupted, or even playfully ridiculed.
**In conclusion:**
Fail safely, learn from failing, be concrete, pay attention, and search for coherent explanations. Do these, and there’s nothing out there you won’t be able to learn.

articles.title: You Don’t Really Exist
articles.description: Identity is but a useful abstraction; not reality.
contents: **Who are you?**
No, I asked not your name, not your occupation nor sunday afternoon pastimes. Who are you?
When I was a kid, I remember a moment where my mother asked me that question. It eventually led me to panic; for every answer I gave, there was a “but is that who you are?”. Who am I?
And yet when you ask me who someone else is, that is a most natural question, with quite simple answers.
**Perception and Abstractions.**

The world is mighty complex. There is too much information for our brain to process entirely, so we must pick and choose. Our perception is directly tied to our cognition in such tangled ways that you’ll see mostly what you already expect (see the 'Invisible Gorilla' experiment).
How do we make sense of such chaos?
Abstractions. Patterns and abstractions.

When we observe the world, different people see different things. If there is such a thing as a unique noumenal world, there is a phenomenal world unique to each of us (the optimist would say that the world is yours… hehe).
These different perceived (phenomenal) worlds come from the different ways we think, and at times differences in our senses (your eyes are not necessarily identical from mine!).
The perception we have is unique to us. And so are our interpretations of what we see.

Our understanding of the world is a mixture: knowledge and stimuli. You perceive, you sense, and you make sense of the information with what you “know” of the world.                    Your reasoning is framed within the constraints of all your previous reasonings, of all that you’ve seen. Every tune, every painting, every smile and every mistake; they all change the way you think.

However your knowledge is finite: we know nothing to an infinite granularity, but only down to a certain level of detail. Rare is the person both aware of the tiniest physics going on inside their nails, and the mind games that rule diplomacy.
In understanding, we must limit detail. We must abstract.
Abstractions. Patterns and abstractions.
The realm of abstractions is too vast, and need not all be explored to show that you don’t exist.
While we abstract in many ways (and quite fascinatingly), let us focus on the abstractions you do every day during your commute: People.

When we perceive Someone Else, we must make sense of the things we sense: the look of their face, their eyes, the sound of their voice or the warmth of their hands. We wrap all of this information into a single agglomeration: a person.

We may accumulate details that we associate with that person: what makes them laugh, their gait, the way they look at the starry sky or yell in traffic. Whether they feel to you as friend or as foe (which, in themselves, are abstractions)                    As we increase detail, we feel we know them more.

When asked who they are, you’ll reply with some subset of these details.                    This is useful. If you had to absorb every bit (pun intended) of information from someone before being able to speak about them, social interactions would be impossibly expensive in time, memory and usage of your brain.
Yet abstractions are useful precisely for the same reason they’re dangerous. They lack detail. They lack nuance.

Abstractions are dangerous when speaking about conflict (think of the idea of the enemy), they’re dangerous when speaking of love, they’re dangerous when listening: if we listen for truth, rather than for abstraction, we’d be misled into an unfounded -yet very strong- sense of confidence.

This lack of granularity means that you’ll never really know who anyone else is. Not entirely. You at most can know them better than anyone else, but if we’re sincere we must recognize that we’ll never know who someone really is.
**The mirror, and why you can’t know yourself.**

When you look in the mirror, what do you see? It is in answering “Myself” that we immediately, inadvertently condemn ourselves to abstraction. The image reflected back at us is merely a surface-level representation, a snapshot of physical appearance that barely scratches the surface of our true essence.

But beyond the physical reflection lies a labyrinth of complexities, contradictions, and ever-changing thoughts and emotions. Attempting to define oneself is akin to grasping at shadows; the more we seek to capture our identity, the more it seems to slip through our fingers.

One might argue that introspection offers a path to self-discovery, a journey inward to uncover the truths that lie buried within our psyche. But even introspection has its limitations, for our perceptions of ourselves are colored by biases, insecurities, and external influences.

And what of the role of memory in shaping our sense of self? Memories are not immutable records of the past but malleable narratives that evolve over time, shaped by selective recall and reinterpretation. Our recollections of past events are filtered through the lens of present consciousness, colored by emotions and perceptions that may distort or embellish the truth.

In the end, the quest to know oneself may be an exercise in futility, a Sisyphean struggle against the tide of impermanence and uncertainty. Perhaps, instead of seeking to define ourselves, we should embrace the enigma of our existence, embracing the fluidity and ambiguity of identity.
For in the absence of a fixed self, there lies the potential for boundless exploration and discovery, a journey of self-discovery that transcends the constraints of definition and limitation.
**Physicality, unity: you melt into the universe.**
We’ve shown that the thought of the self (phenomenal) is water, river, flow. A current that can’t be encapsulated by identity, but that rather flows and bends and chemically mutates through life.
However, the foregoing of the self should also be recognized in the material (noumenal) realm.

It seems an easier question to answer where your body is, where you physically are and of which dimensions. Indeed we have proper ways to measure such things (although I’d invite the reader to ponder what a measurement even is). However: with which detail?

The body is not a static entity but a dynamic ecosystem teeming with life. Consider the trillions of microorganisms that call your body home, from the bacteria in your gut to the fungi on your skin. We are not solitary beings but -mostly- symbiotic organisms, intricately connected to the web of life that surrounds us.

And yet, even within the confines of our own flesh, the boundaries of the self blur and dissolve. The distinction between self and other becomes increasingly nebulous as we delve deeper into the complexities of human biology. What is you and what is foreign? Are you your immune system? The bacteria on your skin? Your microbiota? Your blood? The water in it?

Old cells are continually replaced by new ones in a process of regeneration and renewal. With each passing moment, we shed fragments of ourselves into the world, leaving traces of our existence in the air we breathe, the food we eat, and the earth beneath our feet.                    Are we not but an eternal Theseus ship, whose planks are water and to the ocean return?

Even more atomically, our bodies are not separate from the cosmos but materially joint with it. We are stardust. We are made from universe and held together by it every breath, every step, every laugh and every tear.

When you look at your fingertips thinking “this is where my fingers end”, consider that even there, there are atoms of you further out, and atoms non-you further in. The bounds of the body are as the idea of the body itself, blurry, practical, yet purely conceptual.
When we look up at the night sky, we are not merely observers but participants in a dance of forever, in space and time. We see ourselves, past and future.

So when we ask the question, 'Who are you?' Let us not seek answers in the confines of identity or the boundaries of the body.                     Instead, let us embrace the boundless expanse of being, recognizing that we are not separate from the universe but integral parts of its ever-unfolding story.
When we ask “Who are you?” Let’s reply usefully, socially, with the information the asker needs, yet recognize that the true answer will forever melt between our fingers.
The real answer is simple. The real answer is freeing, liberating. The real answer is harmonious.
You do not exist.

articles.title: On The Limits of Communication: Only You Know What You Know
articles.description: Only you know what you know
contents: **Introduction**

Talk. Code. Read. Write.                     Draw. Sing. Move. Listen.                    The joy of being heard, the connection in eye contact. Communication is the foundation of any social species.                     But at its core, it's only transmitting information.                    Without communication there’s no understanding. No connection. Slow to non-existent progress.
We must communicate; however we often find ourselves struggling with the natural limitations to do so. Why?
**What people teach will never be the same as what people want to learn.**

We’ve all been there. You’re sitting in a classroom, wondering about some detail of what the teacher has explained. You ask a question, and it feels like they’re answering an entirely different one, perhaps you’re so fortunate as to learn something new, but your confusion remains.

At times, we’ve been on the flip side as well. A junior asks you a question on a topic you’ve already explained several times, you answer, and they nod ceremoniously, yet you both know that whatever the motive for their question, it pervades your teachings.                    Despite the teacher's best efforts, the gap between what is taught and what is understood persists.
Frustrating, but why does that happen? Why does it continue to do so across cultures and vocations?
**Context**
Context. Symbols mean naught without context.                    Everything we know, we know within a set of constraints, assumptions and adjacent information.

This set is usually subtextual: it isn’t explicitly signaled anywhere in particular, nor are we even necessarily aware of its existence.                    Yet there is no thought in your mind which would be sensible without context; without the definitions of the words you use to enunciate it, the implicit assumptions you make or the things that you assume everyone must know.

The discrete nature of this contextual information is especially problematic for experts.                    When an expert communicates, they often presume that what they’re saying is obvious or common sense. To them it is, because their contextual knowledge is rich in that field, and so many of their observations are simple consequences of what they know.

We fail -all too frequently- to acknowledge that this context is precisely our expertise, and presuming that this information is widely shared effectively blocks our ability to understand each other, to work together, to hear one another, and to connect sincerely.

Context gets in the way of many other communication based tasks: conflict resolution is harder, when you don’t understand where the other side is coming from, culture is harder to appreciate with just a superficial (context-bare) view, collaboration is hampered by fundamental misunderstandings in the work that must be done or its costs.

On the other end, providing too much context on communicating is often wasteful: it takes time to share, takes time to consume, and most often does not even include the information that the other person actually wants. Even when we attempt to better communicate, we’re permanently impeded from reaching perfection.
Context makes us knowledgeable, yet it seems to impede so much in communicating with each other. We must ponder: is it the context? Or is it us?
I argue that it's not you (context), it's me.
**Only I know what I know:**
People are complicated. We know many, many things.                    However we don’t store our knowledge in shared memory. There is no factual hivemind.
You know what you know, and I know what I know.

But if I ask you “What do you know?”, expecting a list of all the information in your brain you’d find that most ridiculous.                    Even assuming that you could make such a list, you’d fail to communicate it properly (see title of article). But you can’t make such a list.
Why?

“What do you know?” falls, I think, into the same branch of inquiry as questions such as “Who are you?” (which I’ve explored in another article: “You Don’t Really Exist”)                    For most of us, a sufficient limitation to entirely answer these questions is the vagueness of what the question means. What is “knowing” really? What is “me”?

Do I know something if I know where to find it? Do I know something if it has been taught to me by someone else? How can we be sure this other person knew it properly? What does it mean for them to know?

The question of what we know is by nature recursive ad nauseam. There is always the next step of “But how do we know that?” until we reach axiomatic assumptions. Axioms aren’t knowable, they’re simply assumed. So we can assume, and then we can infer from assumptions.
**We can never know**
So… we can’t know things. Voila merci, thank you for your read, let us venture into the streets in cynical dread of our condemnation to eternal ignorance.
This is an unpragmatic interpretation.
I think that there is an alternative interpretation that I find not only infinitely more useful, and more interesting, but also sincerely quite freeing.

Teaching, and indeed any communication, has never been about knowable things. It’s been -and I deem it will forever be- about persuading and convincing each other to exploit useful information, useful methods, useful tools, and useful practices to live better lives. To ask better questions, to solve more important problems.
Thinking of communication as the transfer of the truth is very humane arrogance. We can’t know the truth, not in any real way. But we can know the truth in many useful ways.

Children are excellently transparent with this. For any truth you hold undeniable, they will seamlessly challenge it, with no malice but simple curiosity: because nothing you know is truly undeniable.
But what does all of this tell us about communicating with each other?                    If there is no real fundamental knowledge, but rather just useful snippets, what are we even doing?
**Conclusion: we do our best. But not the best.**

We know nothing, and yet we still… talk. We talk and we write and we sing and we try.                    We communicate our know hows, our warnings, our tales, our stories and advice.                    We communicate to help each other; to help ourselves.                    We do our best.

Yet, let us be permanently conscious: we will never communicate the best way.                    We can’t, so let us be humble. Let us converse, let us keep trying.                    To be imperfect gives us power in iteration, in retrying, in back and forths.

Let’s keep helping each other, but next time a student raises their hand, remember: they can’t ask the perfect question, and you can’t tell them exactly what they want.                    But it's better if you try.

articles.title: Aim to do, not to be.
articles.description: Reflections on the frame of mind that has given me peace and what I deem healthy, sustainable growth.
contents: 'What do you want to be when you grow up?'
Easy to ask, but terrible in its implications.
The greatest tragedy that one can partake in, is believing that one's identity is singular.
Being is a north star
Doing is the path
You must work the soil.

Each remarkable in its own way, one tremendously charming, another greatly intelligent, another beautiful as to offend the olympians.

one_liners: ¡Hola! Mi nombre es Santiago y nací y crecí en México.
paragraphs: mi madre nos dio a mi hermana y a mí el privilegio de asistir a escuelas sofisticadas y aprender inglés. Luego tuve la oportunidad de aprender francés en otro lugar, aún más sofisticado, y obtener varias becas para estudiar lo que más amo en la hermosa tierra del arce, Canadá.
Estoy tratando de convertirme en alguien confiable y competente, para poder devolverle a las personas que me han impulsado hacia adelante.

un estudiante de último año y tutor en la Universidad de Montreal, en el Departamento de Ciencias de la Computación e Investigación Operativa (DIRO). Ha sido un poco extraño comenzar mi carrera durante la pandemia, pero los desafíos únicos que surgieron me han enseñado cosas que no esperaba.

tocar la guitarra; leer, especialmente sobre acción social y temas relacionados con el campo que más amo (no se lo digas a nadie, pero está relacionado con la informática); tengo una extraña obsesión con el agua, sus deportes, especialmente aquellos en los que soy terrible. Como remar con el equipo de UdeM, es bastante divertido gritar sincrónicamente con un grupo de extraños carismáticos mientras intentas desesperadamente no volcarte.

y comunicar la ciencia; he conocido todo tipo de personas a lo largo de mi vida y nuestros diferentes gustos, talentos, experiencias, antecedentes, discapacidades y desafíos me han enseñado más de lo que podría compensar. Eso podría ser la razón por la que terminé enseñando a más de 1500 estudiantes, lo cual, sinceramente, todavía se siente surrealista. Siento que al enseñar, devuelvo un poco de esa deuda y también aprendo mucho, mucho, mucho.

Me he obsesionado un poco con el aprendizaje estadístico, la inteligencia artificial y la visión. ¡Recuerdo cuando era niño y en la escuela nos enseñaron que las computadoras nunca podrían ver! ¡Nunca podrían aprender! Resulta que (como a menudo sucede con lo imposible), ¡solo necesitábamos ser creativos!

people.name: Einstein
people.description: Einstein me inspira por su creatividad impecable, su habilidad para comunicar conceptos científicos complejos con una hermosa claridad y su demostración de que la ciencia no conoce límites. Sus teorías y descubrimientos revolucionarios han transformado nuestra comprensión del universo.

people.name: Oppenheimer
people.description: La historia de Oppenheimer sirve como un recordatorio de que incluso las mentes más brillantes pueden verse envueltas en circunstancias trágicas. Sus contribuciones al desarrollo de la bomba atómica resaltan la importancia de la convicción compasiva y las responsabilidades éticas de los científicos.

people.name: Geoffrey Hinton, Yann Lecun y Yoshua Bengio
people.description: Estos pioneros en el campo de la inteligencia artificial han realizado enormes contribuciones al campo. Lo que realmente me inspira de ellos es su compromiso de hacer que la IA sea accesible para el público y su dedicación para garantizar su uso ético en beneficio de la humanidad.

people.name: Marie y Pierre Curie
people.description: Los Curie ejemplifican la excelencia, el sacrificio y el poder de la colaboración. Su trabajo revolucionario en radioactividad no solo les valió premios Nobel, sino que también los consolidó como una de las parejas más destacadas en la historia de la ciencia.

people.name: Tolstoy, Dostoevsky y Nietzsche
people.description: Estos pensadores influyentes han brindado perspectivas invaluables sobre el trabajo y la condición humana. Sus escritos exploran las profundidades de la experiencia humana, ofreciendo ideas profundas sobre la complejidad de la mente, la búsqueda de sentido y la realización de una vida plena.

people.name: Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz
people.description: La incansable búsqueda de la excelencia de Sor Juana en medio de la discriminación me inspira profundamente. Como una brillante poeta e intelectual durante la era colonial mexicana, desafió las normas sociales y abogó por la educación de las mujeres y la libertad intelectual.

people.name: Frida Kahlo
people.description: La resistencia y valentía de Kahlo al abrazar su ser único resuenan en mí. Su arte refleja su dolor físico y emocional, al tiempo que captura su espíritu indomable y su determinación para superar la adversidad.

people.name: Mandela, Gandhi y Martin Luther King
people.description: Mandela, Gandhi y Martin Luther King encarnan el poder de la resistencia pacífica y el coraje para desafiar sistemas injustos. Su compromiso inquebrantable con la justicia, la igualdad y los derechos humanos sirve como un recordatorio constante de la fuerza del espíritu humano y el impacto transformador que las personas pueden tener en la sociedad.

people.name: Cuauhtémoc Cárdenas
people.description: Cárdenas me inspira con su incansable trabajo por un mejor México. Como político y activista social, ha luchado por la justicia social, la reforma democrática y los derechos de las comunidades marginadas, dejando un impacto duradero en su país.

people.name: Hedy Lamarr
people.description: Hedy Lamarr es una actriz e inventora austriaca que me inspira con su combinación única de belleza, talento artístico e inteligencia científica. Conocida por su exitosa carrera cinematográfica en las décadas de 1930 y 1940, también desempeñó un papel crucial en el desarrollo de la tecnología de comunicación inalámbrica.

thanks: Estoy muy feliz (¡no siempre! evitemos romantizar la felicidad).
Estoy feliz con la vida que llevo, el trabajo que hago y las personas que conozco.
No creo haber hecho algo en particular para merecer esto, pero estoy profundamente agradecido/a.
Con amabilidad, calidez y MUCHO trabajo duro, algunas personas muy especiales me han convertido... en mí, imperfecto pero feliz.

descriptions: Durante el verano de 2022: Implementé características experimentales, documenté y depuré la aplicación web DITA CCMS de Ixiasoft para documentación técnica. Principalmente trabajé con Java, TypeScript, React (por sí solo y con Redux) y Apache. También trabajé, en menor medida, con Maven y CSS.

Durante el verano de 2022: Trabajé bajo la supervisión del profesor titular Stefan Monnier, junto con otro estudiante de licenciatura, para enseñar y calificar una clase de 50 alumnos sobre los conceptos y paradigmas que las principales lenguajes de programación utilizan/pertenecen, a través de Haskell, Lisp (principalmente Elisp), Prolog, C y Java.

Durante el otoño de 2021, el invierno de 2022 y el otoño de 2022: Trabajé bajo la supervisión del profesor titular Marc Feeley y el profesor Olivier Melançon junto con otros 6, 5 y luego 6 estudiantes (respectivamente) para enseñar y calificar una clase de casi 300, luego 150 y luego nuevamente 300 sobre los conceptos básicos de programación, a través de Python.

Durante el otoño de 2021 y de 2022: Trabajé bajo la supervisión del profesor titular Miklós Csűrös con 1 y luego 3 estudiantes de posgrado para enseñar y calificar una clase de 100 y luego 300 sobre las estructuras discretas -y fundamentos- de las matemáticas que más comúnmente utilizamos como científicos de la computación.

Durante el invierno y el otoño de 2022: Trabajé bajo la supervisión del profesor titular Sébastien Roy y luego con la profesora Amal Ben Abdellah. Al principio, con otro estudiante, y luego solo, para enseñar y calificar una clase de 150 alumnos cada vez, sobre cómo funciona Internet, las herramientas que utilizamos en el desarrollo web, así como las mejores prácticas de diseño y cómo construir sus propios sitios web.

descriptions: Este es un proyecto de investigación y desarrollo bajo la supervisión del Instituto de IA de Quebec, Mila.

El clima es caótico, pero modelarlo tiene ventajas, desde la predicción del clima hasta la planificación de eventos, la agricultura y la economía. Por lo tanto, los modelos climáticos a diferentes escalas serían una poderosa herramienta para nuestras sociedades.

Actualmente, tenemos acceso a modelos climáticos globales, pero se basan en mediciones a gran escala. A escalas más pequeñas, los datos pueden ser poco confiables, lo que lleva a conclusiones incorrectas.
Tengo la oportunidad de liderar un equipo que tiene como objetivo construir sobre el estado del arte para resolver este problema como nadie lo ha hecho antes.
Hice un sitio web para ello al que puedes acceder aquí: <lhttps://climate-model-downscaling.web.app/
Este es un proyecto de investigación y desarrollo bajo la supervisión del Instituto de IA de Quebec, Mila.

El análisis de sentimientos es un aspecto muy importante en las empresas, especialmente en términos de experiencia del cliente. De hecho, el análisis de sentimientos es una aplicación de procesamiento del lenguaje natural que tiene como objetivo identificar los diferentes tonos que se encuentran en los textos. Especialmente con la gran ola de popularidad de las redes sociales, el análisis de sentimientos es cada vez más importante.
En este proyecto, exploramos técnicas de aprendizaje automático y aprendizaje profundo en el procesamiento del lenguaje natural (PLN) para identificar sentimientos en textos.
Hice un sitio web para ello al que puedes acceder aquí: <lhttps://causality-text-based-inference.web.app/
Este es un proyecto de investigación y desarrollo para el Laboratorio de Biología Computacional y Teórica de la Universidad de Montreal (UdeM).
Investigué e implementé una API para el refinamiento del ensamblaje del genoma, así como una estructura de datos de esquema de agrupación, utilizando JAVA y la biblioteca htsjdk.
El trabajo está documentado y explicado aquí: <lhttps://genome-assembly-scaffolding.web.app/
Este es un proyecto de investigación y desarrollo para el Laboratorio de Visión por Computadora 3D de UdeM.
Implementé y comparé varias arquitecturas de redes neuronales convolucionales basadas en GC-Net de Kendal et al. Trabajé con Mathematica.
El modelo es capaz de realizar estereoscopía binocular: puede determinar la profundidad basándose en dos imágenes, algo parecido a los ojos humanos.
Principalmente experimenté con variaciones en la profundidad y con el uso de redes residuales, y me interesé tanto en la calidad de la estimación como en el costo computacional.
Puedes acceder al código, análisis y modelos entrenados aquí: <lhttps://github.com/Gfecito/GC-Neat
Trabajé en varios modelos de aprendizaje automático para tareas de aprendizaje supervisado, como regresión y clasificación.
Implementados con Python:
Desde cero: modelos no paramétricos como KNN y ventanas de Parzen (con kernel gaussiano); y modelos paramétricos como perceptrón (regresor logístico) y SVM (con y sin kernel).
Con bibliotecas: redes neuronales, redes neuronales convolucionales (CNN) y SVM.
Y los probé con varias bases de datos, como registros bancarios, registros telefónicos o conjuntos de datos de imágenes (como MNIST).
Implementamos un sistema de gestión de almacenamiento basado en la 'Tabla de Asignación de Archivos' (FAT) utilizando C para un sistema Linux de 32 bits.
En términos sencillos: construimos la sección de administración de archivos (y memoria) de un sistema operativo.
Planifiqué y construí una pequeña base de datos para una biblioteca.
En la planificación, utilizamos métodos formales para el modelado de entidades-relación, luego el modelado relacional, álgebra relacional, optimización de consultas y normalización de bases de datos.
Para la implementación, utilizamos SQL, Hibernate (Java) y Maven para la compilación y entrega del ejecutable.
Particioné y preprocesé una base de datos, construí y entrené un modelo de red neuronal convolucional, lo exporté y luego lo implementé en una plataforma web dinámica.
Construí esta última utilizando Flask (Python) y Jinja.
Una aplicación funcional desarrollada con Java que incluye una interfaz gráfica interactiva y un sistema de gestión de datos.

Pasamos por la rigurosa planificación que se espera de los ingenieros: planificación, entrevistas, priorización, definición de casos de uso, análisis (riesgos, requisitos no funcionales, materiales, restricciones), modelado (VPP), diseño, prototipado, pruebas automáticas (JUnit), gestión y programación de equipos, y por último (pero no menos importante) documentación (Javadoc).
Proyecto escolar para programación orientada a objetos con Java; es una pequeña ventana:

Usando JavaFX, nosotros (2 personas) creamos una ventana elegante con 2 contadores: puedes sumar y restar, dividir y multiplicar, deshacer y rehacer. Cada acción realizada en la aplicación se guardaba temporalmente, por lo que el registro de acciones siempre estaba disponible para exportarlo como un archivo .txt.

Un intérprete Pseudo-Lisp hecho con Haskell: Construí la sección de interpretación y evaluación de un programa Haskell que podía leer y ejecutar archivos de un lenguaje inspirado en Lisp. Manejé funciones, cierre, entornos, variables, recursión y definiciones recursivas, etc... todo el paquete completo.
Luego construí un intérprete Pseudo-Haskell, donde utilicé Prolog para interpretar y ejecutar, con las mismas características que antes, pero con inferencia de tipos añadida.
Utilizando la programación orientada a objetos, creamos un programa de simulación ambiental.

Leía archivos XML que describían animales o plantas y los simulaba durante una cierta cantidad de épocas: la forma en que interactuaban, lo que comían, su consumo de energía, si morían o se reproducían, y demás.
Originalmente creado desde cero con HTML, CSS, JavaScript, jQuery y la biblioteca Animate on Scroll.
Actualmente construido con React, Typescript, JSON, CSS... ¡y un toque de amor!

Desde modelado matemático y biología computacional hasta descubrimiento de medicamentos e inmunología, creo que hay muchas oportunidades para facilitar los avances médicos aprovechando nuestros recursos informáticos. Y ese potencial es, sin duda, la perspectiva más emocionante para mí.

También es natural que me interese después del avance de Google DeepMind en la predicción de la estructura de proteínas y la posterior publicación de su base de datos de predicción. Como si nos dijera: 'sí, puede ser más fácil y rápido. Sí, algunas de tus enfermedades podrían curarse siguiendo este ejemplo'.

Me preocupo por las demás personas, me gustaría que vivan vidas dignas y que puedan disfrutar. También parece obviamente preferible vivir rodeado de personas felices y saludables, que también pueden ayudar, que de otra manera.
No estoy seguro si es el enfoque más eficiente. Pero, ¿a quién le importa cuando puedes ver la sonrisa de alguien a quien has ayudado, aunque sea solo por un momento?

Ahora, me encantan los algoritmos tanto como al cualquier otra persona, pero algunos problemas son muy difíciles de resolver con algoritmos tradicionales. Y resulta que son casi triviales con estos sofisticados (y con demasiada frecuencia oscuros) métodos estadísticos y probabilísticos.
... y sí, también me gustan los autos autónomos, los asistentes personales inteligentes y los artistas de IA.

De hecho, todas las imágenes de la sección de experiencia y las de Medicina, Acción social e IA en la sección de intereses fueron generadas por DALL-E, ¡un modelo de generación de imágenes de Open AI! Que, al igual que el resto de su trabajo, es excelente.
Era el futuro, ahora es el presente.

Nuestra capacidad para interconectar adecuadamente el poder computacional y transferir información de manera eficiente y accesible es, para mí, uno de los mayores avances para la democracia en la historia.
También soy un gran nerd, así que me gustan las matemáticas y la tecnología detrás de todo esto.
Una progresión natural de mi interés en los gráficos, así como mi amor duradero por los juegos, ya sean de video o no.
Siento que el desarrollo de videojuegos me permitiría ser mi yo más creativo, y esa es una persona que me gustaría conocer.

Hay algo fascinante en todos los pequeños trucos matemáticos y psicológicos que hacen que una pantalla en 2D y una calculadora sofisticada engañen a una persona haciéndole creer que está viendo un objeto en 3D. También me gusta que me engañen con objetos 3D bonitos e inexistentes.
Además, las GPU son actualmente los componentes informáticos de desarrollo más rápidos. Me gustaría comprender mejor cómo funcionan para aprovechar todo su potencial.
Bueno, sinceramente, si no te parecen al menos un poco interesantes los robots, no podemos ser amigos.
Hablando en serio, la robótica parece ser el futuro de los procesos y manipulaciones físicas, desde la medicina hasta la fabricación y el transporte.
¿Cómo no voy a estar interesado?
Especialmente cómo lidiar con un espacio físico muy limitado y condiciones físicas adversas para el hardware.
Me interesa saber cómo podríamos programar computadoras que no tienen las mismas comodidades de estabilidad y espacio que nuestras computadoras normales.
¿Cómo aseguramos sistemas mantenibles, rápidos y confiables en estos entornos?

one_liners: Salut ! Je m'appelle Santiago et je suis né et j'ai grandi au Mexique
paragraphs: ma mère nous a offert, à ma sœur et à moi, le privilège de fréquenter des écoles prestigieuses et d'apprendre l'anglais. J'ai ensuite eu l'occasion d'apprendre le français dans un autre endroit - encore plus prestigieux - et d'obtenir plusieurs bourses pour étudier ce que j'aime le plus dans le charmant pays de l'érable, le Canada.
J'essaie de devenir fiable et compétent, afin de pouvoir rendre la pareille à ceux qui m'ont poussé vers l'avant.

un étudiant en dernière année et tuteur à l'Université de Montréal, au Département d'informatique et de recherche opérationnelle (DIRO). Il a été un peu étrange de commencer ma carrière pendant la pandémie, mais les défis uniques qui en ont découlé m'ont appris des choses auxquelles je ne m'attendais pas.

jouer de la guitare ; lire - en particulier sur l'action sociale et les sujets liés au domaine que j'aime le plus (ne le dites à personne, mais c'est lié à l'informatique) ; j'ai une étrange obsession pour l'eau, ses sports, en particulier ceux dans lesquels je suis nul. Comme l'aviron avec l'équipe de l'UdeM, c'est assez amusant de crier synchroniquement avec un groupe d'étrangers charismatiques tout en essayant désespérément de ne pas chavirer.

et communiquer la science ; j'ai rencontré toutes sortes de personnes tout au long de ma vie et nos goûts, talents, expériences, origines, handicaps et défis différents m'ont appris plus que je ne pourrais jamais rembourser. C'est peut-être pourquoi j'ai fini par enseigner à plus de 1500 étudiants - ce qui, honnêtement, semble toujours surréaliste. J'ai l'impression qu'en enseignant, je rembourse un peu de cette dette et j'apprends aussi énormément.

Je suis devenu un peu obsédé par l'apprentissage statistique, l'intelligence artificielle et la vision. Je me souviens quand j'étais enfant, on nous a appris à l'école que les ordinateurs ne pourraient jamais voir ! Ils ne pourraient jamais apprendre ! Il s'avère (comme c'est souvent le cas avec l'impossible) que nous devions simplement faire preuve de créativité !

people.name: Einstein
people.description: Einstein m'inspire par sa créativité impeccable, sa capacité à communiquer des concepts scientifiques complexes avec une clarté magnifique, et sa démonstration que la science ne connaît pas de limites. Ses théories et découvertes révolutionnaires ont remodelé notre compréhension de l'univers.

people.name: Oppenheimer
people.description: L'histoire d'Oppenheimer sert de rappel que même les esprits les plus brillants peuvent être pris dans des circonstances tragiques. Ses contributions au développement de la bombe atomique soulignent l'importance de la conviction compatissante et des responsabilités éthiques des scientifiques.

people.name: Geoffrey Hinton, Yann Lecun et Yoshua Bengio
people.description: Ces pionniers dans le domaine de l'intelligence artificielle ont apporté d'énormes contributions à ce domaine. Ce qui m'inspire vraiment chez eux, c'est leur engagement à rendre l'IA accessible au public et leur dévouement à assurer son utilisation éthique pour le bien de l'humanité.

people.name: Marie et Pierre Curie
people.description: Les Curie incarnent l'excellence, le sacrifice et la puissance de la collaboration. Leurs travaux révolutionnaires sur la radioactivité leur ont non seulement valu des prix Nobel, mais ont également solidifié leur statut de l'un des plus grands couples de pouvoir dans l'histoire de la science.

people.name: Tolstoï, Dostoïevski et Nietzsche
people.description: Ces penseurs influents ont offert des perspectives inestimables sur le travail et la condition humaine. Leurs écrits explorent les profondeurs de l'expérience humaine, offrant des insights profonds sur les complexités de l'esprit, la recherche de sens et la quête d'une vie épanouissante.

people.name: Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz
people.description: La quête inlassable de l'excellence de Sor Juana face à la discrimination m'inspire profondément. En tant que brillante poétesse et intellectuelle pendant l'époque coloniale mexicaine, elle a défié les normes sociales et a milité en faveur de l'éducation des femmes et de la liberté intellectuelle.

people.name: Frida Kahlo
people.description: La résilience et le courage de Kahlo à embrasser sa propre singularité résonnent en moi. Son art reflète sa douleur physique et émotionnelle, tout en capturant son esprit inébranlable et sa détermination à surmonter l'adversité.

people.name: Mandela, Gandhi et Martin Luther King
people.description: Mandela, Gandhi et Martin Luther King incarnent le pouvoir de la résistance pacifique et le courage de défier des systèmes injustes. Leur engagement inébranlable envers la justice, l'égalité et les droits de l'homme nous rappelle constamment la force de l'esprit humain et l'impact transformateur que peuvent avoir les individus sur la société.

people.name: Cuauhtémoc Cárdenas
people.description: Cárdenas m'inspire par son travail inlassable pour un meilleur Mexique. En tant que politicien et militant social, il a lutté pour la justice sociale, la réforme démocratique et les droits des communautés marginalisées, laissant ainsi une empreinte durable sur son pays.

people.name: Hedy Lamarr
people.description: Hedy Lamarr est une actrice et inventrice autrichienne qui m'inspire par sa combinaison unique de beauté, de talent artistique et d'intelligence scientifique. Connue pour sa carrière cinématographique réussie dans les années 1930 et 1940, elle a également joué un rôle crucial dans le développement de la technologie de la communication sans fil.

thanks: Je suis très heureux/se (pas toujours ! ne romantisons pas le bonheur).
Je suis heureux/se de la vie que je mène, du travail que je fais et des personnes que je connais.
Je ne pense pas avoir fait quelque chose de particulier pour mériter cela, mais je suis profondément reconnaissant/e.
Avec gentillesse, chaleur et BEAUCOUP de travail acharné, certaines personnes très spéciales ont fait de moi... moi, imparfait(e) mais heureux/se.

descriptions: Il s'agit d'un projet de recherche et développement supervisé par Mila - Institut québécois d'intelligence artificielle

Le climat est chaotique, mais le modéliser présente des avantages, de la prévision météorologique à la planification d'événements, en passant par l'agriculture et l'économie. Ainsi, les modèles climatiques à différentes échelles pourraient être un outil puissant pour nos sociétés.

Actuellement, nous avons accès à des modèles climatiques mondiaux, mais ils sont basés sur des mesures à grande échelle. À plus petite échelle, les données peuvent être peu fiables, ce qui conduit à des conclusions incorrectes.
J'ai l'opportunité de diriger une équipe dont l'objectif est de construire sur les avancées technologiques pour résoudre ce problème comme personne ne l'a jamais fait auparavant.
J'ai créé un site Web pour cela auquel vous pouvez accéder ici : <lhttps://climate-model-downscaling.web.app/
Il s'agit d'un projet de recherche et développement supervisé par Mila - Institut québécois d'intelligence artificielle

L'analyse de sentiment est un aspect très important pour les entreprises, en particulier en ce qui concerne l'expérience client. En effet, l'analyse de sentiment est une application de traitement du langage naturel qui vise à identifier les différents tons présents dans les textes. Surtout avec l'énorme vague de popularité des médias sociaux, l'analyse de sentiment devient encore plus importante.
Dans ce projet, nous explorons les techniques d'apprentissage automatique et d'apprentissage profond en traitement du langage naturel (NLP) pour identifier les sentiments dans les textes.
J'ai créé un site Web pour cela auquel vous pouvez accéder ici : <lhttps://causality-text-based-inference.web.app/
Il s'agit d'un projet de recherche et développement pour le Laboratoire de biologie computationnelle et théorique de l'UdeM
J'ai étudié et implémenté une API pour le raffinement de l'assemblage du génome, ainsi qu'une structure de données pour le regroupement, en utilisant JAVA et la bibliothèque htsjdk.
Le travail est soigneusement documenté et expliqué ici : <lhttps://genome-assembly-scaffolding.web.app/
Il s'agit d'un projet de recherche et développement pour le Laboratoire de vision par ordinateur 3D de l'UdeM
J'ai mis en œuvre et comparé plusieurs architectures de réseaux de neurones convolutifs basées sur GC-Net de Kendal et al. J'ai travaillé avec Mathematica.
Le modèle est capable de faire de la stéréoscopie binoculaire : il peut déterminer la profondeur en se basant sur deux images, un peu comme les yeux humains !

J'ai principalement expérimenté avec des variations de profondeur et l'utilisation de réseaux résiduels, et j'ai été intéressé par la qualité de l'estimation ainsi que par les ressources informatiques nécessaires.
Vous pouvez accéder au code, à l'analyse et aux modèles entraînés ici : <lhttps://github.com/Gfecito/GC-Neat
Travail sur divers modèles d'apprentissage automatique pour des tâches d'apprentissage supervisé, telles que la régression et la classification
Implémenté avec Python :

À partir de zéro : des modèles non paramétriques tels que KNN et Parzen Windows (avec un noyau gaussien) ; et des modèles paramétriques tels qu'un perceptron (régresseur logistique) et un SVM (avec et sans noyau)
Avec des bibliothèques : réseaux de neurones, CNN et SVM
Et testés avec plusieurs bases de données, comme des relevés bancaires, des relevés téléphoniques ou des ensembles de données d'images (comme MNIST)
Nous avons mis en place un système de gestion de stockage basé sur la 'File Allocation Table' en utilisant le langage C pour un système Linux 32 bits.
En termes simples : nous avons construit la section de gestion des fichiers (et de la mémoire) d'un système d'exploitation.
Planifié puis construit une petite base de données pour une bibliothèque

Dans la phase de planification, nous avons utilisé des méthodes formelles pour la modélisation entité-relation, puis la modélisation relationnelle, l'algèbre relationnelle, l'optimisation des requêtes et la normalisation de la base de données.
Pour l'implémentation, nous avons utilisé SQL, Hibernate (Java) et Maven pour la compilation et la livraison de l'exécutable.
Partitionné et prétraité une base de données, construit et entraîné un modèle de réseau de neurones convolutifs, exporté puis implémenté dans une plateforme Web dynamique.
J'ai construit cette dernière en utilisant Flask (Python) et Jinja.
Une application fonctionnelle développée en Java qui comprend une interface graphique interactive et un système de gestion des données.

Nous avons suivi la planification rigoureuse attendue des ingénieurs : planification, entretiens, priorisation, définition des cas d'utilisation, analyse (risques, exigences non fonctionnelles, matériaux, contraintes), modélisation (VPP), conception, prototypage, tests automatiques (JUnit), gestion d'équipe et planification, et enfin (mais non des moindres) documentation (Javadoc).
Projet scolaire en programmation orientée objet avec Java ; c'est une petite fenêtre :

À l'aide de JavaFX, nous (2 personnes) avons créé une fenêtre élégante avec 2 compteurs : vous pouvez ajouter et soustraire, diviser et multiplier, annuler et rétablir. Chaque action effectuée dans l'application était temporairement sauvegardée, de sorte que le journal des actions était toujours disponible pour être exporté sous forme de fichier .txt.

Un interpréteur pseudo-Lisp réalisé en Haskell : J'ai construit la section d'interprétation et d'évaluation d'un programme Haskell capable de lire et d'exécuter des fichiers d'un langage inspiré du Lisp. J'ai traité des fonctions, des fermetures, des environnements, des variables, de la récursion et des définitions récursives, etc... tout y est.

Ensuite, j'ai construit un interpréteur pseudo-Haskell, où j'ai utilisé Prolog pour l'interprétation et l'exécution, avec les mêmes fonctionnalités qu'auparavant, mais avec une inférence de type ajoutée.
À l'aide de la programmation orientée objet, nous avons créé un programme de simulation environnementale.

Il lisait des fichiers XML décrivant des animaux ou des plantes et les simulait pendant un certain nombre d'époques : leur interaction, ce qu'ils mangeaient, leur consommation d'énergie, s'ils mouraient ou se reproduisaient, etc.
Initialement créé à partir de zéro avec HTML, CSS, JavaScript, jQuery ainsi que la bibliothèque Animate on Scroll.
Actuellement construit avec React, Typescript, JSON, CSS... et une pincée d'amour !

De la modélisation mathématique et de la biologie computationnelle à la découverte de médicaments et à l'immunologie, je pense qu'il y a beaucoup d'opportunités pour faciliter les avancées médicales en tirant parti de nos ressources informatiques. Et ce potentiel est sans aucun doute la perspective la plus excitante pour moi.

C'est également tout naturel que je m'intéresse à la percée de Google DeepMind dans la prédiction de la structure des protéines, ainsi qu'à la publication ultérieure de leur base de données de prédictions. Comme si cela nous disait : 'oui, cela peut être plus facile et plus rapide. Oui, certaines de vos maladies pourraient être guéries en suivant cet exemple.'

Je me soucie des autres, j'aimerais qu'ils vivent une vie digne et qu'ils puissent s'amuser. Il semble évident qu'il est préférable de vivre entouré de personnes heureuses et en bonne santé - qui peuvent également aider - plutôt que le contraire.
Je ne suis pas sûr que ce soit l'approche la plus efficace. Mais qu'importe lorsque vous pouvez voir le sourire de quelqu'un que vous avez aidé, ne serait-ce qu'un peu ?

Maintenant, j'adore les algorithmes autant que n'importe qui d'autre, mais certains problèmes sont très difficiles à résoudre avec des algorithmes traditionnels. Et ils se résolvent presque trivialement avec ces méthodes statistiques et probabilistes sophistiquées (et trop souvent obscures).
... et oui, j'aime aussi les voitures autonomes, les assistants personnels intelligents et les artistes en IA.

En fait, toutes les images de la section expérience, ainsi que celles de Médecine, Action sociale et IA dans la section des intérêts, ont été générées par DALL-E ! Un modèle de génération d'images d'Open AI ; qui, comme le reste de leur travail, est excellent.
C'était le futur, c'est maintenant le présent.

Notre capacité à connecter correctement la puissance de calcul et à transférer des informations de manière efficace et accessible est, selon moi, l'une des plus grandes avancées de l'histoire de la démocratie.
Je suis aussi un énorme nerd, donc j'aime les mathématiques et la technologie qui les soutient.
Une progression naturelle de mon intérêt pour le graphisme, ainsi que mon amour de longue date pour les jeux - vidéo ou autres.
J'ai l'impression que le développement de jeux me permettrait d'être moi-même le plus créatif possible, et c'est une personne que j'aimerais rencontrer.

Il y a quelque chose de fascinant dans tous les petits tours de mathématiques et de psychologie qui permettent à un écran en 2D et à une calculatrice sophistiquée de tromper une personne en lui faisant croire qu'elle regarde un objet en 3D. J'aime aussi être trompé par de jolis objets 3D qui n'existent pas.
De plus, les GPU sont de loin les composants informatiques les plus rapides en développement de nos jours. J'aimerais vraiment mieux comprendre leur fonctionnement pour exploiter tout leur potentiel.
Franchement, si vous ne trouvez pas les robots au moins un peu cool, nous ne pouvons pas être amis.
Sur une note plus sérieuse, la robotique semble être l'avenir des processus physiques et des manipulations, partout de la médecine à la fabrication et au transport.
Comment pourrais-je ne pas m'y intéresser ?!
Notamment comment faire face à un espace physique très limité et à des conditions physiques défavorables pour le matériel.
Je suis intéressé par la façon dont nous pourrions programmer des ordinateurs qui n'ont pas les mêmes avantages en termes de stabilité et d'espace que nos ordinateurs normaux.
Comment assurer des systèmes maintenables, rapides et fiables dans ces environnements ?
